channel.title: Combined Politepol Feed
channel.description: Merged feed from multiple Politepol sources

item.title: Will the US really annex Greenland? What a new bill reveals
Student, hairdresser, coach... The stories of those killed in Iran’s protests
US labels Muslim Brotherhood as terrorist group. What you need to know
FirstUp: US Supreme Court to rule on tariffs, Denmark & Greenland officials to meet Vance, Rubio... The news today
Explained: China’s claim to India’s Shaksgam Valley and the Pakistan connection
No more 10-minute delivery from Blinkit, Swiggy. Here is why
Why world should ignore Trump’s mockery of global leaders
item.description: President Trump mocking foreign leaders publicly makes even neutral international public dislike his behaviour, and it has little tangible or intangible gain for the US, which he statedly aims to ‘make great again’

item.title: Trumpism and the way forward for India
item.description: The future trajectory of relations will depend heavily on how both nations manage their divergent economic and foreign policy priorities

item.title: Why Dhaka should revisit China’s sinister role in the 1971 war
item.description: The shadows of the past—specifically China’s initial resistance to Bengali sovereignty—offer a sobering lesson in 'realpolitik' that remains relevant even today

item.title: It’s not the ‘Don-Roe Doctrine’: Silly US interventionism validated Putin’s invasion and gave China a playbook
item.description: Donald Trump is not reviving the empire so much as exposing its limits. The very need to assert hemispheric dominance so explicitly suggests that such dominance is no longer taken for granted

item.title: Pakistan’s Gaza deception: How Gen Munir said yes, meant no, and fooled Trump
item.description: Islamabad’s response to the Gaza peacekeeping proposal reveals a familiar pattern: Say yes to Washington, signal no at home, and let someone else take the blame

item.title: Ukraine to Venezuela: India’s geopolitical strategy amidst global turbulence
item.description: The world has moved from a predictable, albeit tense, Cold War bipolarity to a fluid, contested system defined by rising powers, intertwined economies, technological competition, and challenges to traditional state power
